title: As the executor of an estate, how will unpaid tax liens and foreclosure of the decedents home effect me?
question: I am the executor of my late mother's estate and just discovered unpaid income taxes, which has resulted in a lien on the estate. I was in the process of selling her home, but have learned that due to the lien, I will now owe money in order to close the sale. There is no money left in the estate to pay the lien, cover closing costs or to continue paying mortgage bills, and I am afraid that the home may go into foreclosure. At this point, I am tempted to walk away from the home and the lien, since what I have inherited is a lot of debt and headache. As the executor of the estate, how will the unpaid lien and potential foreclosure effect my credit, if at all?
answers:
You do not owe any money. Your mother's estate owes money.

It sounds like you can either walk away, or if you want to do the most honorable thing possible, work with the lender on a short sale. If you don't want to put in the time for a short sale, the lender may be willing to have you deed the property to them.

You don't say if your mother had a trust or will. If trust, deeding the property to the lender will be straightforward. If a will, you should get court approval.

Good luck!

As the executor, you have a duty t maximize the value fot he estate for the beneficiaries, if the estate is "upside down" dues to these liens and debts, there may be nothing you can do to preserve the estate's value. Your best options may be to negotiate a short sale with your buyer and the lender for an amount that covers the debts, or offer a Deed in Lieu to the lender if the amount of the sale you were contracting for and that the lender approved doesn't cover the debts.

No, if the lender forecloses on the mortgage it won't affect your personal credit, which has nothing to do with your acts in your capacity as executor of this estate.
